metadata.description: Architectural definitions for biological systems from molecular to ecosystem scale
metadata.purpose: Enable modeling of gene networks, metabolic pathways, protein interactions, and ecological systems
key_references: Systems Biology: A Textbook (Klipp et al.)
Cytoscape and BioPAX standards for biological networks

biological_component.definition: A functional unit in a biological system that performs biological functions and interacts with other components
characteristics: Has internal state (concentration, expression level, activity, population size)
Performs biological functions (catalysis, regulation, signal transduction)
Interacts through molecular mechanisms or ecological relationships
Can exist at multiple scales simultaneously

interaction.definition: A relationship where one biological component affects the state, behavior, or function of another

activation.definition: Component A increases activity, expression, or concentration of B

inhibition.definition: Component A decreases activity, expression, or concentration of B

transport.definition: Component moves across membrane or cellular compartment

competition.definition: Both organisms negatively affected by resource competition
examples: Two species compete for same food source

directionality.directed: Clear source → target (e.g., gene regulation, predation)
directionality.feedback: Output feeds back to input (e.g., negative feedback loop in metabolism)

biological_function.definition: Internal process or capability that a component performs

level_0.name: System Classification
level_0.purpose: Determine the biological scale and system type

molecular_network.description: Gene regulatory networks, metabolic pathways, signaling cascades

cellular_system.description: Single cell or cell type with internal subsystems

multicellular_organism.description: Organism with multiple organs and tissues

ecological_network.example: Yellowstone ecosystem with wolves, elk, vegetation

level_1.name: Primary Decomposition
level_1.purpose: Identify major functional modules or components
characteristics: Distinct biological functions (e.g., glycolysis vs gluconeogenesis)
Clear interfaces via shared metabolites, signals, or interactions

level_2.name: Detailed Component Specification
level_2.purpose: Define individual genes, proteins, species with their interactions

level_3.name: Deep Mechanistic Detail (Optional)
level_3.purpose: Model structural biology, molecular dynamics, or individual organism behavior
trigger_conditions: Need stochastic effects (low copy number molecules)

experimentally_validated.definition: Component or interaction confirmed by experimental data

computationally_predicted.definition: Predicted by computational models or sequence analysis

hypothetical.definition: Inferred to exist based on knowledge gaps or indirect evidence

boolean_networks.description: Gene regulatory networks with binary ON/OFF states
boolean_networks.example: Yeast cell cycle network, mammalian cell cycle checkpoints

ordinary_differential_equations.description: Continuous dynamics of concentrations over time

stochastic_models.description: Account for random fluctuations in small populations or low copy numbers

agent_based_models.description: Individual entities (cells, organisms) with autonomous behavior
agent_based_models.node_representation: Individual agents with position, state, behavior rules
agent_based_models.example: T-cell migration in lymph node, ant colony foraging

constraint_based_models.description: Metabolic networks analyzed via stoichiometry and constraints

network_topology.example: Scale-free properties of PPI networks, trophic cascades in food webs

network_topology_validation.purpose: Verify network structure matches known biology

perturbation_validation.purpose: Model predicts effects of knockouts, overexpression, drug treatment

cross_scale_consistency.purpose: Ensure molecular-level and organism-level models are consistent
cross_scale_consistency.method: Multiscale modeling integrating molecular and cellular scales

robustness.definition: System maintains function despite genetic or environmental perturbations

metrics.name: knockout_tolerance
metrics.measurement: Fraction of genes that can be deleted without lethality

metrics.name: parameter_sensitivity
metrics.measurement: Change in output per unit change in parameter

evolvability.definition: Capacity for adaptive evolution and innovation

metrics.name: mutational_robustness
metrics.measurement: Fraction of mutations that are neutral

metrics.name: phenotypic_plasticity
metrics.measurement: Range of phenotypes from same genotype

efficiency.definition: Optimal use of resources (energy, nutrients, time)

stability.definition: System returns to equilibrium after perturbation

metrics.name: eigenvalue_analysis
metrics.measurement: All eigenvalues have negative real part

sensitivity.definition: Ability to detect and respond to signals

metrics.name: signal_amplification
metrics.measurement: Output change per unit input change

network_motifs.description: Recurring circuit patterns in biological networks with specific functions

feedforward_loop.structure: A → B → C and A → C
feedforward_loop.function: Filters noise, delays response, creates pulse

feedback_loop.structure: A → B → A (positive) or A ⊣ B → A (negative)
feedback_loop.function: Positive: bistability, amplification. Negative: homeostasis, oscillations

unexplained_phenotype.definition: Observable trait or behavior not explained by known components
unexplained_phenotype.example: Knockout of gene X causes phenotype Y, but no known function of X relates to Y

orphan_regulation.definition: Gene expression changes without identified transcription factor
orphan_regulation.example: Gene upregulated in condition A, but no known regulator binds promoter
orphan_regulation.implication: Missing transcription factor or signaling pathway

metabolic_dead_end.definition: Metabolite produced but no known consuming reaction
metabolic_dead_end.example: Compound X accumulates, no downstream enzyme identified

missing_link_in_pathway.definition: Known input and output but intermediate steps unknown
missing_link_in_pathway.example: Signal A leads to outcome B, but pathway components unclear
missing_link_in_pathway.implication: Missing signaling intermediates (like dark matter in physics)

phylogenetic_gap.definition: Gene present in distant species but absent in intermediate lineages
phylogenetic_gap.example: Gene in bacteria and humans but not in intermediate eukaryotes
phylogenetic_gap.implication: Horizontal gene transfer or convergent evolution

Gene.definition: DNA sequence encoding RNA or protein

Protein.definition: Functional biomolecule with enzymatic or structural role

Species_Population.definition: Group of organisms of same species in ecosystem

Pathway.definition: Sequence of reactions or interactions achieving biological function
